Description: Body sherd (mended from two fragments with added plaster) of Chian Mature Animal Style pottery heavy chalice; white slip; interior: glazed black; from top: chain of palmettes and buds with rosettes in added white and red; two faded white bands; white and red buds alternating with concentric circles; exterior: painted decoration consisting of tail and rump with red patch of sphinx to left; at right, part of standing sphinx (face, part of wing, body and upper part of foreleg remaining with red patches on wing, body and leg), to left; elaborate rosettes, lozenges and dots as filling ornament.
Curator's comments: The sherd belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1888,0601.466.g. Lemos describes the sherd as coming from a heavy chalice belonging to the Group of Elaborate Animal Chalices. Chalices that fall into this group are usually large and heavy-walled and are also known as chalice kraters. Chalices in this group display elaborate compositions that include polychromy and delicately painted figures (Lemos 1991, 90-1).
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 90, p. 121, p. 123, fig. 65, p. 255, no. 440, pl. 59)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1567) (phase 2)
